meanings.definition: Able to be measured or compared in relation to another.
meanings.sent1: The length of the two ropes was commensurable, making it easy to compare them.
meanings.sent2: In science, it is important to have commensurable units for accurate measurements.
meanings.sent3: The cat thought it was commensurable to compare its tail to a snake, much to the amusement of the onlookers.
meanings.sent4: Her kindness was commensurable to a warm hug on a cold day, bringing comfort to those around her.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used colorful blocks to make the concept of commensurable sizes more vivid for the students.

meanings.definition: Having a common measure or unit of comparison.
meanings.sent1: The two countries had commensurable currencies, making trade between them easier.
meanings.sent2: It is essential for all team members to have commensurable goals for effective collaboration.
meanings.sent3: The idea of measuring happiness in 'smiles per hour' seemed commensurable to a child's imagination.
meanings.sent4: Their friendship was commensurable to a sturdy bridge, connecting them through thick and thin.
meanings.sent5: The artist used different shades of blue to show the commensurable depths of the ocean in her painting.
